full_summary:
### Government Contract Invitation - Polled Ins
#### Engagement Overview

Defence Construction Canada (DCC) is inviting consulting firms to submit abbreviated proposals for the provision of contaminated site and environmental compliance consulting services. The selected consultants will be part of a source list, intended to support the Department of National Defence in Nunavut.

The engagement is subject to the Nunavut Agreement and the Treasury Board of Canada Secretariat's Directive on Government Contracts, including real property leases, in the Nunavut settlement area.

#### Services Offered

The chosen consultants will provide on-demand services, including:

* Contaminated site assessment and remediation
* Environmental compliance assessments and guidance
* Risk assessments and mitigation strategies
* GIS support and data analysis
* Drafting and geotechnical engineering services

####.Preference for Inuit Firms

DCC has confirmed the presence of two or more Inuit firms on the Inuit Firm Registry, eligible to provide the required services. As per the Treasury Board of Canada Secretariat's Directive, this procurement is restricted to registered and In good standing Inuit firms.

####Engagement Requirements

The source list will be active for one year, with a maximum estimated value of $2,000,000. The selection process will be based on the evaluation of proposals using established criteria, focusing on Inuit and Nunavut benefits in employee hiring, training, and skills development. Subcontracting to Inuit firms and the location of offices in the Nunavut settlement area are also key considerations.

####Bidding Process

Interested firms can submit abbreviated proposals through the MERX Electronic Bidding System before the closing date and time (January 30, 2023, at 2:00 PM). Further information, including contract award results, is available on the DCC website (contract activity - Defence Construction Canada).

####Trade Agreements

Canada's trade agreements, including the Comprehensive and Progressive Agreement for Trans-Pacific Partnership (CPTPP) and the Canada-Europe Union Comprehensive Economic and Trade Agreement (CETA), do not apply to this procurement. Indigenous peoples and businesses will, however, benefit from the inclusion of measures that promote Indigenous participation.
